Quota from https://github.com/containernetworking/cni/releases/tag/v0.8.0
> We do not release binaries here: this repo holds the Specification and Go Library for CNI; the plugins have moved to https://github.com/containernetworking/plugins.

- https://github.com/containernetworking/plugins/releases/tag/v0.9.1 on Feb 5th.
- https://github.com/containernetworking/cni/releases/tag/v0.8.1 on Feb 2th.

comments.body:
this appears to add a parser/interpreter. some questions about the capabilities this exposes:
1. does the user have to do anything to opt into kustomize loading/evaluating code with this intepreter?
2. is code this interprets loaded from files on disk? if so, how are the paths specified, and can they be arbitrary or are they bounded to kustomize directories or other specific directories?
3. is code this interprets loaded over the network? if so, how are the source URLs specified?
4. what capabilities does the code this interprets have access to? can it load other files or make network calls? can it consume arbitrary CPU/memory?

Starlark provides the possibility of a starlark-based plugin.  A user must install configuration for said plugin and add `-enable-star` to the `kubectl kustomize` command to allow the config to be honored.   It's marked alpha, we're not obligated to keep it.  I understand your concerns.  I'd prefer to remove the flag from kubectl than perform a security review in this PR.  Unfortunately, I cannot promise to remove the dep as well and make codefreeze.

As long as it requires explicit opt-in from the user and is not enabled/exposed by default, I won't block on this. Long-term, the flag and dep should be partitioned so they can be imported/registered together, and not need to be part of the dependency tree if unused.

Please open a kustomize issue to track dropping the `go-openapi/{analysis,validate,strfmt}` deps in a future release... these have really questionable transitive dependencies (like a mongodb driver(!) - go.mongodb.org/mongo-driver) that are getting added here.

Those deps prompted extracting the bits needed for openapi validation of custom resources out to https://github.com/kubernetes/kube-openapi/tree/master/pkg/validation - if that has what you need to switch over (or a couple small additions would enable you to switch to it) that would be a much smaller dependency set.
(and please link the issue back here once it's open)
Opened https://github.com/kubernetes-sigs/kustomize/issues/3705
@monopole we are getting someone to write proper tools for surfacing stuff like we caught here ( by visual inspection :) )

comments.body: Shouldn't this come with a go.sum change?

I think `github.com/godbus/dbus/v5` is already a transitive dependency used by runc which is vendored into k/k:

```
$ go mod why -m github.com/godbus/dbus/v5
# github.com/godbus/dbus/v5
k8s.io/kubernetes/pkg/kubelet/cm
github.com/opencontainers/runc/libcontainer/cgroups/systemd
github.com/godbus/dbus/v5
``` 

`github.com/godbus/dbus/v5` is already included in go.sum: https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/master/go.sum#L215-L216

I think because it's already included, there's no need for additional `go.sum` change.

comments.body:
This loopback dependency (where a nested module depends on a parent component that is not a module with a module-incompatible version tag) is ... interesting. I'm not sure what issues this could cause in the future.

Looking closer, I can't actually figure out why this dependency was added... there's no code in the base repo, and all subpackages declare their own modules... seems like this could just be dropped as a dependency by the `github.com/Azure/go-autorest/*` modules
weird, looks like this was added in https://github.com/Azure/go-autorest/pull/528 ... I'm still not sure why having all the submodules reference a parent containing no code is desired

comments.body:
Notable things in the release notes for these releases:

* 1.26
  * dns: disable SRV record lookups unless grpclb is imported (#3149)
  * dns: stop polling for updates; use UpdateState API (#3165)
* 1.25
  * clientconn: override authority with address's ServerName, if set (#3073) Special Thanks: @jpbetz

@jpbetz, can you verify these don't impact the etcd client, and help us understand if upgrading grpc underneath the etcd client is reasonable? (as a point of reference, the current version of the etcd client we use, 3cf2f69b5738fb702ba1a935590f36b52b18979b aka v3.4.3, expects grpc v1.23.1 - https://github.com/etcd-io/etcd/blob/3cf2f69b5738fb702ba1a935590f36b52b18979b/go.mod#L46)

"clientconn: override authority with address's ServerName" (grpc/grpc-go#3073) is safe. I've run https://github.com/jpbetz/etcd/commit/aa6a86e3e86b3a9a7781ac8685b8952613ed61f5#diff-3aa2435f0785d80e2f2472b60d17f905 against etcd v3.4.3 with grpc 1.26.0 to verify (https://github.com/jpbetz/etcd/pull/new/grpc1.26.0-verify contains the test code I used).

"dns: disable SRV record lookups unless grpclb is imported" (grpc/grpc-go#3149) looks okay as well. etcd uses it's own dns SRV lookup code (https://github.com/etcd-io/etcd/blob/master/pkg/srv/srv.go), not the grpc code. I verified etcd srv discovery still works with grpc 1.26.0 via:

```
<edit go.mod, set grpc to 1.26.0>
make build-docker-dns-srv-test
make docker-dns-srv-test-certs-run
```

"dns: stop polling for updates; use UpdateState API" (grpc/grpc-go#3165) does not appear to cause problems for the etcd client. It already returns the appropriate error from build if there are no connections available (https://github.com/etcd-io/etcd/blob/master/clientv3/balancer/balancer.go#L89). Tested this via:

```
# edit go.mod, set grpc to 1.26.0
# run etcd server in a terminal
# edit /etc/hosts, set etcd1.home to an valiid IP of 127.0.0.1
$ bin/etcdctl --endpoints=etcd1.home:2379 put a success
# edit /etc/hosts, set etcd1.home to an invalid IP of 127.0.0.2
$ bin/etcdctl --endpoints=etcd1.home:2379 get a
{"level":"warn","ts":"2020-01-14T13:54:12.152-0800","caller":"clientv3/retry_interceptor.go:61","msg":"retrying of unary invoker failed","target":"endpoint://client-73ef456f-aa89-43b9-9829-b9d75bf622af/etcd1.jpbetz.home:2379","attempt":0,"error":"rpc error: code = DeadlineExceeded desc = latest
 balancer error: all SubConns are in TransientFailure, latest connection error: connection error: desc = \"transport: Error while dialing dial tcp 127.0.0.2:2379: connect: connection refused\""}

$ bin/etcdctl --endpoints=etcd1.jpbetz.home:2379 get a --command-timeout=5m --dial-timeout=5m
# edit /etc/hosts, set etcd1.home to an valid IP of 127.0.0.1
success
```

Looks like the changes to grpc are okay from an etcd perspective. I was reasoned through each one briefly and constructed a test to verify the behavior remains as we expect. Please have a quick look at my methodology here with a critical eye. I'm happy to dig deeper if any sees points out any gaps in how I've tested these changes.
^ @jingyih and @yoyinzyc let me know if you're aware of how the above test methodology might miss anything important

> ^ Jingyi Hu and Yuchen Zhou let me know if you're aware of how the above test methodology might miss anything important

Generally looks good. Do we need to test sending request through [grpc gateway](https://github.com/etcd-io/etcd/blob/master/Documentation/dev-guide/api_grpc_gateway.md)?

comments.body:
Is there a reason to do this downgrade in 506ddeeb70ed6b904074f730376bf10a5b617155? The diff inside the lib https://github.com/prometheus/client_model/compare/14fe0d1b01d4...v0.1.0 shows that there are no go related changes, other than the fact that they have removed protobuf-stuff for other languages in `v0.1.0`.

So in fact this will just revert @dims PR https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/87093. (minus https://github.com/prometheus/client_model/commit/14fe0d1b01d4d5fc031dd4bec1823bd3ebbe8016)

Haven't tested it, but if there is no difference I guess keeping the tagged version would be preferred?

comments.body: The `build/root/WORKSPACE` configuration specifies exactly `go_version=1.13.4`. Worth doing the same here?

Only major+minor is used, so when running go 1.13.4, you get the following result:
```bash
> go mod init example
go: creating new go.mod: module example
> cat go.mod  
module example

go 1.13
```

So we should stick to `go 1.13`

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +5,9 @@module k8s.io/kubernetes

go 1.13

require (

comments.body: what pulled this in?
Only called pin-dependencies and update-vendor. But interesting indeed.

`go-openapi/strfmt`.  It got support for Mongo's bson format. 

We should immediately start restricting the supported formats to what we have in 1.16. I fear we get more and more format without noticing.

Agree. This is concerning, both from what it exposes in our API, and what it pulls in as dependencies. I think we need to open upstream issues requesting things like this be split so all downstreams don't pick up this dependency, or look into replacing this library long term.

> We should immediately start restricting the supported formats to what we have in 1.16.

do we restrict format today? or is it allowed to be arbitrary and some special values just get magical validation behavior from go-openapi?

even if we lock down our API surface, I don't want to pick up dependencies like this, so I don't think we should take this unless we have a plan for dropping it
Agreed.  We need a very tight control of public APIs, and do not want to be dependent on dependencies for api stability.
https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/85223 as a first step.

> do we restrict format today? or is it allowed to be arbitrary and some special values just get magical validation behavior from go-openapi?

By definition formats are best effort to be checked by OpenAPI implementors. We allow any format string. go-openapi checks two handful of format strings, see PR.
https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/85381 looks good for controlling our API surface.

@sttts pointed out that our openapi validation library already required a mongo driver library to do bsonobjectid validation (github.com/globalsign/mgo). this drops that unofficial mongo code (7771 lines worth) in favor of the official driver (13402 lines worth).

I'm ok with the following plan:
1. control api surface in https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/85381
2. merge this to fix the items validation bug
3. open issue upstream in openapi-validator/strfmt to see if they'll refactor to drop the mongo dep
4. open an issue in k/k consider ways to clean up and control our openapi validator dependency, even if it means extracting the narrow pieces we depend on
github.com/globalsign/mgo replaced by go.mongodb.org/mongo-driver, the former unmaintained according to the go-openapi project.

comments.body: @jpbetz what version of go is etcd 3.4.3 building with? this is the go1.13 version of golang.org/x/net, but we are still pinned to the 1.12 version (until https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/issues/82531 lands)
etcd v3.4.3 is built with go version 1.12.12 https://github.com/etcd-io/etcd/blob/v3.4.3/Makefile#L54. What shall I do this golang.org/x/net  dependency then?

we're still pinned to the go1.12 version of golang.org/x/net with our replace statement, so we're ok, but this means etcd is building/testing with a mix of a go1.12 runtime and a go1.13-level golang.org/x/net library (which @jpbetz might want to reconcile)
@jpbetz do you know why etcd chose this version of `golang.org/x/sys`? it is not the go1.12 or go1.13 branch version
I see that both golang.org/x/sys and the above golang.org/x/net were specifically added to support Risc-V in this PR https://github.com/etcd-io/etcd/pull/10834
looks good

comments.body: Do we know why this changed?

Looks like https://github.com/golang/oauth2/blob/master/go.mod added a go.mod file requiring this version. 

I'm afraid to ask, but what dependencies does bumping this to its preferred level bring in? See https://github.com/kubernetes/community/blob/master/contributors/devel/sig-architecture/vendor.md#adding-or-updating-a-dependency for why leaving dependencies pinned older than their minimum preferred version is problematic

looks like this is a tiny dependency 👍 

go ahead and bump this to it's preferred level as well:

```
hack/pin-dependency.sh cloud.google.com/go v0.34.0
hack/update-vendor.sh
```

Yeah it looks like Kubernetes' only uses cloud.google.com/go/cloud/metadata which, since 2017 (https://github.com/googleapis/google-cloud-go/commit/43376517fff0a0afae99886e3cba67018699c873#diff-4ff99412e0bc1122c84694ea4f62b8b1), has had 0 external dependencies:

```
$ ag '"cloud.google.com/go'
pkg/cloudprovider/providers/gce/gce.go
32:     "cloud.google.com/go/compute/metadata"

pkg/cloudprovider/providers/gce/gce_instances.go
27:     "cloud.google.com/go/compute/metadata"

pkg/cloudprovider/providers/gce/gce_util.go
36:     "cloud.google.com/go/compute/metadata"

vendor/cloud.google.com/go/internal/BUILD
7:    importpath = "cloud.google.com/go/internal",

vendor/cloud.google.com/go/compute/metadata/BUILD
7:    importpath = "cloud.google.com/go/compute/metadata",

vendor/cloud.google.com/go/compute/metadata/metadata.go
20:package metadata // import "cloud.google.com/go/compute/metadata"
38:     "cloud.google.com/go/internal"

vendor/github.com/grpc-ecosystem/go-grpc-middleware/Gopkg.lock
5:  name = "cloud.google.com/go"

vendor/github.com/google/cadvisor/utils/cloudinfo/gce/gce.go
24:     "cloud.google.com/go/compute/metadata"

vendor/golang.org/x/oauth2/google/google.go
24:     "cloud.google.com/go/compute/metadata"

vendor/golang.org/x/oauth2/google/default.go
16:     "cloud.google.com/go/compute/metadata"

```

comments.body: I don't get it - these seem to be a duplication of the require block above - what's this about?

`require` notes a dependency of k8s.io/kubernetes on the given module at the given version (but go is free to pick a newer version if there are conflicting dependencies anywhere in our dependency graph)

`replace` pins the given module to the given version.

you need both in the top-level module being built to ensure that no dependency silently changes the versions you're pulling in.
that seems super pointless - why would we `require` a specific tag only to have go change that under us?  I can see how it might matter for version ranges, but it seems pointless for examct specs?

welcome to go module [minimal version selection](https://github.com/golang/go/wiki/Modules#version-selection):

> The minimal version selection algorithm is used to select the versions of all modules used in a build. For each module in a build, the version selected by minimal version selection is always the semantically highest of the versions explicitly listed by a require directive in the main module or one of its dependencies.

comments.body: What did you run to do this work?  Why are we blindly updating some deps?

most of the commits have associated commands (`go mod init`, `go mod tidy`, `hack/update-vendor.sh`, etc). before this exits WIP, each commit will have a reproducible command associated/documented.

I'm actually trying to figure out why `go mod tidy` is bumping this particular dependency right now...

turns out go aggressively rewrites your go.mod file require statements to reflect the version of the referenced that will actually be used for the build, based on `max(local require, transitive dependency require...)`

the local `replace` can still stomp and pin to a particular version (which we do), but in this case, one of our dependencies was requiring v1.1.0, so our local require statement got bumped up:

```
$ go mod graph | grep github.com/PuerkitoBio/purell
k8s.io/kubernetes github.com/PuerkitoBio/purell@v1.1.0
github.com/go-openapi/loads@v0.17.0 github.com/PuerkitoBio/purell@v1.1.0
github.com/go-openapi/spec@v0.17.2 github.com/PuerkitoBio/purell@v1.1.0
github.com/go-openapi/loads@v0.17.2 github.com/PuerkitoBio/purell@v1.1.0
github.com/go-openapi/spec@v0.17.0 github.com/PuerkitoBio/purell@v1.1.0
github.com/go-openapi/jsonreference@v0.19.0 github.com/PuerkitoBio/purell@v1.1.0
github.com/go-openapi/jsonreference@v0.17.0 github.com/PuerkitoBio/purell@v1.1.0
```
all the commands (including the initialization commands used to take master from current state to this PR) are now baked into `hack/update-vendor.sh`
